To achieve greater therapeutic effect, it is essential that the polymer should have higher drug loading efficiency for sustained release of the drug. Higher drug loading and encapsulation efficiency can be achieved by use of appropriate particle size and adequate optimization of the fabrication parameters. Extensive optimization of the conditions to
prepare 5-fluorouracil-loaded PLGA NPs with Eudragit S100 using oilin-oil solvent evaporation technique led to the development of a nanoformulation with an enhanced drug loading efficiency and a sustained release of 120 h at a pH of 7.4 (Wang et al., 2013c).

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text:
The use of nanoscience and technology in the area of targeted drug delivery has witness a major surge in the last two decades, mainly with a purpose to maximize therapeutic benefit (efficacy) and minimize toxicity (safety). Polymeric nanoparticle based drug delivery systems have demonstrated several advantages over conventional macro drug delivery systems. In this regard, natural biodegradable polymer based nanoparticle drug delivery systems have proved to be a promising, viable, and a safe option for controlled release of drugs. These nanoformulations are superior to macroformulations or traditional formulations in the context of controlled release, targeted delivery and therapeutic effect. Additionally, they can help in reducing dosing frequency, while safeguarding stability and preserving the structure. This has become possible due to several reasons such as their ability to target specific organs and tissues, increase bioavailability, solubility and permeability of potent drugs, can act as DNA carriers in gene therapy and deliver large molecules such as proteins, peptides and genes through oral administration. With the availability of wide variety of natural biodegradable polymers there is tremendous scope for the development of safe and efficient drug delivery systems. However, pertinent issues in the search, design and development have to be carefully addressed. This includes adequate drug incorporation in the formulation with efficient release, sufficient biodistribution, biocompatibility, specificity in targeting, stability of the formulation and shelf life. Still a lot of ground has to be covered to enhance and realize the full potential of nanomedicines. This article presents the current understanding and scope of natural biodegradable polymer based nanoformulations for drug delivery. Further, different methods for preparation and characterization are discussed in detail along with significant features of selected formulations for drug delivery.

metadata.abstractText: Nanomedicines are now considered as the new-generation medication in the current era mainly because of their features related to nano size. The efficacy of many drugs in their micro/macro formulations is shown to have poor bioavailability and pharmacokinetics after oral administration. To overcome this predicament, use of natural/synthetic biodegradable polymeric nanoparticles (NPs) have gained prominence in the field of nanomedicine for targeted drug delivery to improve biocompatibility, bioavailability, safety, enhanced permeability, better retention time and lower toxicity. For drug delivery, it is essential to have biodegradable nanoparticle formulations for safe and efficient transport and release of drug at the intended site. Moreover, depending on the target organ, a suitable biodegradable polymer can be selected as the drug-carrier for target specific as well as for sustained drug delivery. The aim of this review is to present the current status and scope of natural biodegradable polymers as well as some emerging polymers with special characteristics as suitable carriers for drug delivery applications. The most widely preferred preparation methods are discussed along with their characterization using different analytical techniques. Further, the review highlights significant features of methods developed using natural polymers for drug entrapment and release studies.
